messages.content:
Experiment Plan: Predictive Modeling of BA Degree Completion Using Machine Learning

Develop a predictive model to classify whether a respondent completes a BA degree based on their socio-demographic and academic background. Use machine learning techniques such as decision trees, random forests, or support vector machines to build the model. Evaluate the model's performance using metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. This analysis aims to identify key predictors of BA degree completion and assess the model's ability to generalize to new data.
messages.name: user_proxy

messages.content: {"hypothesis":"Socio-demographic and academic background variables can be used to accurately predict BA degree completion, with key predictors including SES, class percentile, and race.","dimensions":{"contexts":["Participants of the NLS dataset","Secondary school graduates"],"variables":["Socio-demographic background","Academic background","BA Degree Completion"],"relationships":[{"explanatory":"Socio-demographic and academic background","response":"BA Degree Completion","relationship":"predictive"}]}}
messages.name: hypothesis_generator

messages.content:
{"code":"from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, precision_score, recall_score, f1_score, classification_report

# Prepare the data for modeling
X = df[['SES', 'PERCENTILE IN CLASS', 'SAMPLE_SEX', 'SAMPLE_RACE']]
X = pd.get_dummies(X, drop_first=True)  # Convert categorical variables to dummy variables
y = df['BA DEGREE COMPLETED']

# Split the data into training and testing sets
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.3, random_state=42)

# Initialize and train the Random Forest Classifier
rf_model = RandomForestClassifier(random_state=42)
rf_model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Make predictions on the test set
y_pred = rf_model.predict(X_test)

# Evaluate the model's performance
accuracy = accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred)
precision = precision_score(y_test, y_pred)
recall = recall_score(y_test, y_pred)
f1 = f1_score(y_test, y_pred)

# Print the evaluation metrics
print("Accuracy:", accuracy)
print("Precision:", precision)
print("Recall:", recall)
print("F1 Score:", f1)

# Print the classification report
print("\nClassification Report:\n", classification_report(y_test, y_pred))"}

- **Accuracy**: The model achieved a high accuracy of 97.4%, which is misleading due to the class imbalance.
- **Precision, Recall, and F1 Score for Class 1 (BA Degree Completed)**: All these metrics are 0.0, indicating that the model failed to correctly identify any instances of BA degree completion. This suggests that the model is biased towards predicting the majority class (non-completion).
- **Classification Report**: The precision, recall, and F1-score for class 0 (non-completion) are high, but for class 1, they are all zero, confirming the model's inability to predict the minority class.

The results highlight the need for addressing class imbalance, possibly through techniques such as resampling, using different algorithms, or adjusting class weights, to improve the model's ability to predict BA degree completion accurately."}

messages.content: {"experiments":[{"title":"Exploring the Impact of Family Size on Academic Performance","description":"Conduct an analysis to explore the relationship between family size and academic performance, as measured by the class percentile. This experiment will involve using linear regression to model the class percentile as a function of family size, controlling for other factors such as SES, race, and gender. The goal is to determine if larger family sizes are associated with lower or higher class percentiles, providing insights into how family dynamics might influence academic success."},{"title":"Time-Series Analysis of Socioeconomic Trends in Education","description":"Perform a time-series analysis to explore trends in socioeconomic status (SES) and educational attainment over time. Analyze how SES and the likelihood of completing a BA degree have changed over time, and identify any significant trends or patterns. This analysis can provide insights into the evolution of educational inequality and the impact of socioeconomic factors over time."},{"title":"Clustering Analysis of Socio-Demographic Profiles","description":"Conduct a clustering analysis to identify distinct socio-demographic profiles within the dataset. Use clustering algorithms such as K-means or hierarchical clustering to group respondents based on variables like SES, race, gender, family size, and academic performance. The goal is to uncover natural groupings or segments within the population that share similar characteristics. This analysis can help identify patterns and relationships that are not immediately apparent and provide a deeper understanding of the diversity within the dataset."}]}

messages.content:
{"code":"from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, precision_score, recall_score, f1_score, classification_report

# Prepare the data for modeling
X = df[['SES', 'PERCENTILE IN CLASS', 'SAMPLE_SEX', 'SAMPLE_RACE']]
X = pd.get_dummies(X, drop_first=True)  # Convert categorical variables to dummy variables
y = df['BA DEGREE COMPLETED']

# Split the data into training and testing sets
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.3, random_state=42)

# Initialize and train the Random Forest Classifier
rf_model = RandomForestClassifier(random_state=42)
rf_model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Make predictions on the test set
y_pred = rf_model.predict(X_test)

# Evaluate the model's performance
accuracy = accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred)
precision = precision_score(y_test, y_pred)
recall = recall_score(y_test, y_pred)
f1 = f1_score(y_test, y_pred)

# Print the evaluation metrics
print("Accuracy:", accuracy)
print("Precision:", precision)
print("Recall:", recall)
print("F1 Score:", f1)

# Print the classification report
print("\nClassification Report:\n", classification_report(y_test, y_pred))"}

messages.content:
{"code":"from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, precision_score, recall_score, f1_score, classification_report

# Prepare the data for modeling
X = df[['SES', 'PERCENTILE IN CLASS', 'SAMPLE_SEX', 'SAMPLE_RACE']]
X = pd.get_dummies(X, drop_first=True)  # Convert categorical variables to dummy variables
y = df['BA DEGREE COMPLETED']

# Split the data into training and testing sets
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.3, random_state=42)

# Initialize and train the Random Forest Classifier
rf_model = RandomForestClassifier(random_state=42)
rf_model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Make predictions on the test set
y_pred = rf_model.predict(X_test)

# Evaluate the model's performance
accuracy = accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred)
precision = precision_score(y_test, y_pred)
recall = recall_score(y_test, y_pred)
f1 = f1_score(y_test, y_pred)

# Print the evaluation metrics
print("Accuracy:", accuracy)
print("Precision:", precision)
print("Recall:", recall)
print("F1 Score:", f1)

# Print the classification report
print("\nClassification Report:\n", classification_report(y_test, y_pred))"}

This analysis can provide insights into the evolution of educational inequality and the impact of socioeconomic factors over time."},{"title":"Clustering Analysis of Socio-Demographic Profiles","description":"Conduct a clustering analysis to identify distinct socio-demographic profiles within the dataset.
